p: These finding raise concerns about whether patients with negative respiratory swabs are truly virus-free, or sampling of additional body sites is needed. Therefore, it may be important to routinely detect viral RNA in stool specimens of COVID‐19 patients during the hospitalization and recovery stage, and to perform transmission‐based precautions for patients until the negative conversion of viral RNA in feces. According to reports to date, no patients showed positive results for viral RNA in pharyngeal swabs reversibly after the anal swabs turned negative [ 47].
